node.title: Changing timestepper type during a solve.
node.bodyText:
Is there a way to change timestepper type during a solve?  E.g. start with a FunctionDT for exactly defined time steps, and then allow an IterationAdaptive timestepper to take over at a defined point.
start_time and end_time in the Transient Executioner block apply to all settings, not just the timestepper.
Can this be done using TimePeriod controls?  If so, how are these cross-referenced between the Executioner and Controls blocks?
Or can sub-blocks with appropriate start and end times be specified within the main Executioners block (similar to defining sub-blocks for a stitched mesh)?
I can't seem to find any specific examples of the syntax showing how to do these if they are possible.
Alternatively, do the parameters "time_t" and "time_dt" allow some specific timestep values to be set within an IterationAdaptiveDT timestepper?  Is there an example of this syntax?
These two previous questions and answers seem to have related information, but are for more specific cases reacting to values obtained during a solve:
#23344
#23414
I'm trying to set up some defined times at the start of a solve, so this should be much simpler (I think).

Hello
Not currently. You currently cannot build two timesteppers.
However @MengnanLi91 is designing a composition time stepper that will bring a lot of flexibility to this, and will less you specify more than one time stepper.
See #23961
Guillaume

OK.  Thanks for this.  This should be a useful addition.
In the meantime is there an example using the parameters "time_t" and "time_dt" in the existing IterationAdaptiveDT timestepper?  I'm not sure if these will help me do what I want.

There's an example here
(modules/tensor_mechanics/test/tests/anisotropic_elastoplasticity/ad_uniaxial_x.i)
does it work as expected?

Unfortunately, this isn't doing what I'd hoped for.  I expected the "time_dt" values to be default time step values which are applied after each corresponding "time_t" value.  But this isn't what happened.
It might easier to explain what I'd like to happen.
Initially, up to t = 600, I'd like the equivalent of this FunctionDT:

type = FunctionDT
function = 'if(t<60, 6, 30)'

Then after this, from t = 600:

type = IterationAdaptiveDT
dt = 24
cutback_factor = 0.5
growth_factor = 2


So the timestep could be cut back to 12, 6 (or smaller), but if possible it will grow, maybe applying a maximum value of 192 (or larger depending on circumstances).
I tried to do a version of this using:

[TimeStepper]
type = IterationAdaptiveDT
dt = 6
cutback_factor = 0.5
growth_factor = 2
time_t = '0 60 600 624'
time_dt = '6 30 6 24'
[]

And I got this set of time values up to 600.  So the time step is growing and shrinking by factors which aren't 2 or 0.5.

time
0
6
14.4
26.16
42.624
60
90
118.6667
146.0593
172.2344
197.2462
221.1464
243.9843
265.8072
286.6602
306.5865
325.6271
343.8214
361.2071
377.8201
393.6948
408.8639
423.3589
437.2096
450.4447
463.0916
475.1764
486.7241
497.7586
508.3027
518.3781
528.0058
537.2055
545.9964
554.3965
562.4234
570.0934
577.4226
584.426
591.1182
597.513
600

Above 600, it did move between, 3, 6, 12 and 24.  But wouldn't go above 24.  So I have misunderstood what the array of values specified in the parameters do.
Can what I want be achieved using:

force_step_every_function_point
timestep_limiting_function
max_function_change

Use this as the limiting function
'if(t<60, 6, 30)'
then once you are done with limiting, just use another if to make it blow away
if(t<600, if(t<60, 6, 30),    10000000)

It says:

*** ERROR ***
The following error occurred in the object "TimeStepper", of type "IterationAdaptiveDT".
timestep_limiting_function must be a PiecewiseBase function

So it doesn't seem I can use a ParsedFunction with nested ifs.
My broader query was why the timestep increased and decreased by factors other than the specified 2 and 0.5, and then didn't increase to higher timestep values even though the model was solving OK.

I've found a way to do it.
I couldn't use "ifs" with a timestep_limiting_function, but I can with a timestep_limiting_postprocessor using a parsed function.
So this TimeStepper block and associated PPs do something like what I wanted.

[TimeStepper] # Sub-block to vary default timestep during different stages of solve.
type = IterationAdaptiveDT
optimal_iterations = 6
iteration_window = 3
linear_iteration_ratio = 3
growth_factor = 2
cutback_factor = 0.5
dt = 6
timestep_limiting_postprocessor = P999_tslim_pp
[]


[Postprocessors]
[P999_tslim_pp]
type = ParsedPostprocessor
function = 'if(t<60, 6,
if(t<540, 60,
if(t<660, 6, 1536)))'
pp_names = 'P998_dummy_pp'
use_t = true
[]
[P998_dummy_pp]
type = EmptyPostprocessor
[]
[]

The timesteps are controlled up to 660s, and held at 6s for 600s +/- 60s where I'm changing something in my model.
Then after 660s the brakes are taken off and the full adaptive timestep capability is allowed to let rip.

ah I m glad you found a way. I think we will be able to do this easier in the future with the CompositionDT.
Best,
Guillaume

node.title: the following blocks (ids) do not exist on the mesh
node.bodyText:
After compiling, I drew a grid myself and imported it into MOOSE for calculation. However, the following error occurred during runtime：

/mnt/d/projects/hc/hc.i:41: (Materials/example/block):
    the following blocks (ids) do not exist on the mesh: solid-hex (65535)

application called MPI_Abort(MPI_COMM_WORLD, 1) - process 0
[unset]: write_line error; fd=-1 buf=:cmd=abort exitcode=1
:
system msg for write_line failure : Bad file descriptor


Here is my i file：
[Mesh]
  file = cube.exo
  
[]
[Variables]
  [./heatc]
    order = FIRST
    family = LAGRANGE
  [../]
[]
[Kernels]
  [./diff]
    type = rechuandao 
    variable = heatc 
  
  [../]
  [./conv]
    type = shijianpiandao
    variable = heatc
    
  [../]
[]
[BCs]
  [./bottom] 
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = heatc
    boundary = 'bottom' # This must match a named boundary in the mesh file
    value = 300
  [../]

  [./top] 
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = heatc
    boundary = 'top' # This must match a named boundary in the mesh file
    value = 1000
  [../]
[]
[Materials]
  [./example]
    type = hmaterial
    block = 'solid-hex'
    k=1
    cp=500
    density=1000
    
  [../]
 # [./example1]
  #  type = hmaterial
   # block = 'solid-hex'
   # k=10
    #cp=600
    #density=2000
  #[../]
[]
[Executioner]
  type = Transient
  solve_type = 'PJFNK'
  num_steps = 10
  dt = 1
[]
[Outputs]
  exodus = true # Output Exodus format
[]



The grid body I created using pointwise is named solid, and when I use paraviw to view the grid file, the blocks ID is solid hex

Hello
Can you either

run your input with --mesh-only in the command line and paste the output here
use a FileMeshGenerator instead of just file= then use the show_info parameter and paste the output here
Thank you!

Guillaume
Sorry, as I just learned MOOSE, I don't quite understand what you're saying about how to operate it
./xx-opt -i xxx.i --mesh-only

node.title: Whether the finite element order is different in generating the preprocessing matrix and solving the equation？
node.bodyText:
Hello everyone! May I ask a question?
I have an idea to use linear finite element to generate preprocessing matrix M and quadratic element to solve it, but I don't know whether this idea can be realized in moose or petsc? How can I do that?
Lily

So you want your M and J to represent a first order basis and second order basis respectively? If that is what you're asking, this is not currently possible in MOOSE. We supply the same matrix for both M and J

Thank you for your help!
Lily

node.title: Piecewise Bilinear Interpolation of Variable Values
node.bodyText:
Hello,
I am wondering if there is a way to compute a piecewise bilinear output based on variables other than spatial coordinates and time? I have a boundary that varies as a function of pressure and time; however, the variation cannot be defined with an analytical expression and must be interpolated. Using a function BC that pulls a value from a PiecewiseBilinear function seems like the right approach, but I don't think there is a way to interpolate within PiecewiseBilinear with quantities other than space and time as it is currently written. Is there a way to accomplish this without writing a custom kernel?

Hello
Typically, variable dependence is not for Functions. Functions are pre-determined functions of time and space.
You ll want to look at a material property instead. If it s just for output (and only output) you can consider an auxkernel too.
If the dependencies are simple, you can use a ParsedMaterial.
If they are complicated, you ll want to code but there are good utilities for performing these operations
These utilities are shared across different systems. In PiecewiseBilinear function, you can look at the _bilinear_interp member of the class, it s something you can create in your custom material to do the interpolations
Guillaume

node.title: [PorousFlow] Volume fraction and BCs
node.bodyText:
Hi,
I currently use PorousFlow with volume flow using GlobalParams multiply_by_density = false.
My problem is 1 phase - 2 component flow, pore pressure and a tracer.
I want to inject a constant volume flow of a mixture at an inlet, so for example 1 m3/s with volume fraction component_0 = 0.1 (tracer) and component_1 = 0.9 (pore pressure), and I'm not sure which BCs to apply and which 'use_' options to put there.
Unlike most kernels, PorousFlowSink doesn't provide the 'multiply_by_density = false' option and I'm not sure if it's even needed there. So the explanation on the homepage is not quite clear to me.
[GlobalParams]
  PorousFlowDictator = dictator
  gravity = '0 0 -9.81'
  multiply_by_density = false        # make it volumetric
[]
[BCs]
  [pout]
    type = DirichletBC # ensure outlet on model top 
    variable = pp
    boundary = outlet_area
    value = 0
  []
  [flow_inj]
    type = PorousFlowSink  # constant tracer injection; vol. flow rate = 1 m3/s with 0.1 tracer vol concentration
    boundary = 'inlet_area'
    variable = pp
    flux_function = '-0.9' # inlet area is 1x1 m, so q(inj)= 1m/s
    use_relperm = true 
    fluid_phase = 0
 []
 [comp_inj]
    type = PorousFlowSink
    boundary = 'inlet_area'
    variable = volfrac0
    flux_function = '-0.1'
    use_relperm = true
    fluid_phase = 0
  []
[]

I am unsure if I am even on the right track with this approach?
Best regards

Hello
The porousFlowSink contributes : function * test * local relative permeability.
So as long as the function is in the same units as your variables, and you are consistent about using the relative permeability, I think you are on the right track.
@WilkAndy the function parameter description says the unit is kg.m^-2.s^-1. Is this still true when in 'volume flow' with multiply_by_density = false everywhere else?
Guillaume

Great question @1runer .    When you use multiply_by_density = false, the flux_function of PorousFlowSink is measured in m^3.m^-2.s^-1.
Please think carefully about whether you want to use multiply_by_density = false.  Eg, quoting from PorousFlowFullySaturated:
"When not multiply by density, in many situations the sum of Eq. (1) will imply a Laplace equation such 0=∇(k(∇P−ρg)), that is a steady-state distribution for the porepressure. In addition, care must be taken when using other parts of PorousFlow, for instance, the PorousFlowMass Postprocessor is coded to record fluid mass, not fluid volume"

Thanks @WilkAndy  and @GiudGiud  for the confirmation.
The idea is that it is rather common in the literature and also in other codes to calculate component transport and saturation in volume fractions and accordingly most material properties or mixing equations are designed for volume flow. I am aware that for the dissolution of salts and gases it is somewhat different considering molar masses etc.
"Eq. (1) PorousFlowFullySaturated will imply a Laplace equation such 0=∇(k(∇P−ρg))"
My very naive (and probably stupid) question: what are the practical implications for the results or simulation of multiplying both sides of the equation by 1 rather than the fluid density? For convergence reasons this is understandable. Is there further literature regarding this?

node.title: Performance Graph
node.bodyText:
Hello,
I want to do a runtime measurement of my main app and I am only concerned about the performance of the main app. Is it possible to measure only the main app runtime and memory usage, without the contribution of the sub-apps or do I have to change the main-sub structure of my application?
All the best
Philip

Hello
Use the perf_graph in the main app and manually substract the multiapps portion from the total.
You should be able to get the multiapps share in the main app, but if not, then use the perf graph in the subapp as well.
Guillaume
I'd try that. I've never done it so please let us know how it goes

Okay, that was also my first idea.
So I have a main app and I am only interested in the time it takes to calculate one timestep within the main app. The sub-app only loads data and does mesh translation, which I do not want to measure.
So I look at the
|                                   Section                                  | Calls |   Self(s)  |   Avg(s)   |    %   | Mem(MB) |  Total(s)  |   Avg(s)   |    %   | Mem(MB) |

|     MooseApp::execute                                                      |     1 |      0.000 |      0.000 |   0.00 |       0 |     42.512 |     42.512 |  98.74 |      38 |
|       MooseApp::executeExecutioner                                         |     1 |      0.007 |      0.007 |   0.02 |       1 |     42.512 |     42.512 |  98.74 |      38 |
|         Transient::PicardSolve                                             |     3 |      0.030 |      0.010 |   0.07 |       4 |     41.416 |     13.805 |  96.20 |      24 |


and divide it by the number of time steps: 41.416s / 4timestep ~ 10s/timestep.
I assume that in this measurement the runtime of the Transient::PicardSolve of my sub-app is included, but not the time it takes to set up the sub-app. Then I can subtract
sub-app0: |                                 Section                                | Calls |   Self(s)  |   Avg(s)   |    %   | Mem(MB) |  Total(s)  |   Avg(s)   |    %   | Mem(MB) |

sub-app0: |   Transient::PicardSolve                                               |     3 |      0.004 |      0.001 |   0.01 |       0 |      1.982 |      0.661 |   4.62 |      -5 |


Resulting in a runtime of ~ 41.416s / 4timestep-1.982s /4timestep ~ 9.5s/timestep.
Should I consider more of the execution time?
Philip

This seems fine to ignore the setup tasks.
If you are trying to draw conclusions from this, you ll like want to execute these timings on several independent runs btw
they can vary from one execution to the other

Thank you. That helps a lot.
Yes this will need to be automated so that I can do several runs with several settings. Is there a Python tool for reading out the PerfGraf JSON file?
Philip

@loganharbour any tips
We dont distribute one afaik, though i m sure there's something to read JSON files in python

Okay, now I am confused :)
I think that the  Performance Graph does some sort of double bookkeeping. Here are both the Performance Graph:
For the sub-app
sub0: Performance Graph:
sub0: --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
sub0: |                                Section                               | Calls |   Self(s)  |   Avg(s)   |    %   | Mem(MB) |  Total(s)  |   Avg(s)   |    %   | Mem(MB) 
sub0: | SealionTestApp (sub0)                                                |     1 |     42.861 |     42.861 |  93.55 |      17 |     45.815 |     45.815 | 100.00 |     111 |
sub0: |   Transient::PicardSolve                                             |     3 |      0.003 |      0.001 |   0.01 |       0 |      1.612 |      0.537 |   3.52 |      -5 |

And for the main-app
Performance Graph:
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
|                                 Section                                | Calls |   Self(s)  |   Avg(s)   |    %   | Mem(MB) |  Total(s)  |   Avg(s)   |    %   | Mem(MB) |
| SealionTestApp (main)                                                  |     1 |      0.005 |      0.005 |   0.01 |       2 |     45.975 |     45.975 | 100.00 |     137 |

|     Transient::PicardSolve                                             |     3 |      0.026 |      0.009 |   0.06 |       3 |     44.296 |     14.765 |  96.35 |      24 |


First of all my main app should be the heaviest part of the calculation. So that got me confused. Then I ran it by changing the number of nodes in the main-app while keeping the sub-app constant.
That results in the Performance Graph of the sub-app appearing to "run" faster.
sub0: Performance Graph:
sub0: --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
sub0: |                                Section                               | Calls |   Self(s)  |   Avg(s)   |    %   | Mem(MB) |  Total(s)  |   Avg(s)   |    %   | Mem(MB) |
sub0: --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
sub0: | SealionTestApp (sub0)                                                |     1 |      0.367 |      0.367 |  11.63 |       2 |      3.154 |      3.154 | 100.00 |      97 |

So I assume that the performance graphs are not truly separated?
Philip

This line is not
sub0: | SealionTestApp (sub0)                                                |     1 |     42.861 |     42.861 |  93.55 |      17 |     45.815 |     45.815 | 100.00 |     111 |

but this line is
sub0: |   Transient::PicardSolve                                             |     3 |      0.003 |      0.001 |   0.01 |       0 |      1.612 |      0.537 |   3.52 |      -5 |

the perf graph takes differences between start and end points. It s pretty simple. PicardSolve is solidly inside the MultiApp, however the first line of the graph is simply a counter started at the app initialization

Ahh, I see.
So the main app Transient::PicardSolve tells me the total time spent on Transient::PicardSolve and the sub app Transient::PicardSolve tells me the time the sub app spends there.
The first lines just tell me how long the main app needed to initialize the sub app.
Thank you
Philip

First line is closer to the entire simulation time actually
And PicardSolve in the main app includes the subapp run time

"First line is closer to the entire simulation time actually"
yes, I meant the difference between the two.
"And PicardSolve in the main app includes the subapp run time"
The PicardSolve subapp run time?

node.title: Copy mesh to sub app when using mortar contact
node.bodyText:
Hi all, I am trying to use mortar contact in the main app and phase field in the sub app. I want to copy the mesh to the sub app and tried the option clone_parent_mesh=true but get an error:
*** ERROR ***
We should be adding geometric rms so early that we haven't set our MeshBase yet

I wonder what is the correct setting to copy mesh to the sub app.
here is part of my input files：
main.i
[MultiApps]
  [fracture]
    type = TransientMultiApp
    input_files = fracture.i
    cli_args = 'E=${E};K=${K};G=${G};Lambda=${Lambda};Gc=${Gc};l=${l};sigma_ts=${sigma_ts};sigma_cs=${sigma_cs};delta=${delta}'
    execute_on = 'TIMESTEP_END'
    clone_parent_mesh = true
  []
[]

[Transfers]
  [from_d]
    type = MultiAppCopyTransfer
    from_multi_app = fracture
    variable = 'd'
    source_variable = 'd'
  []
  [to_psie_active]
    type = MultiAppCopyTransfer
    to_multi_app = fracture
    variable = 'disp_x disp_y strain_zz psie_active'
    source_variable = 'disp_x disp_y strain_zz psie_active'
  []
[]

[Mesh]
  coord_type = XYZ
  [fmg]
    type = FileMeshGenerator
    file = '../mesh/disk_mortar_flat.msh'
    ### for recover
    # use_for_exodus_restart = true
    # file = './out/solid_R14.5_ts10_cs80_l0.25_delta25.e'
  []
  patch_size = 10
  patch_update_strategy = always
[]

sub.i
[Mesh]
  coord_type = XYZ
  [fmg]
    type = FileMeshGenerator
    file = '../mesh/disk_mortar_flat.msh'
    ### for recover
    # use_for_exodus_restart = true
    # file = './out/solid_R14.5_ts10_cs80_l0.25_delta25.e'
  []
  # # patch_update_strategy = auto
[]

Hello
Just dont use clone_parent_mesh.
It doesnt save anything, you can just create the mesh in the subapp the same way as the main app
Guillaume
should I also use the same patch_size and patch_update_strategy in sub app?

weirdly, even if I use the same mesh setting:
[Mesh]
  coord_type = XYZ
  [fmg]
    type = FileMeshGenerator
    file = '../mesh/disk_mortar_flat.msh'
    ### for recover
    # use_for_exodus_restart = true
    # file = './out/solid_R14.5_ts10_cs80_l0.25_delta25.e'
  []
  patch_size = 10
  patch_update_strategy = always
[]

I still get an error in copy transfer:
The following error occurred in the object "to_psie_active", of type "MultiAppCopyTransfer".

The meshes must be identical to utilize MultiAppDofCopyTransfer::transfer.�[39m
the meshes must be identical. Is the patching changing the mesh differently in either mesh?
no I am using the same patch_size = 10 patch_update_strategy = always
kk. Just use a shape evaluation transfer. It wont complain
THe meshes must be different in some way. I m not familiar with patch_update enough to know why
ok, I will try, thanks

If you are using the Contact action, by default you will be adding additional mesh generators from there, unless you set generate_mortar_mesh = false. To use that option, you would have to have already added the lower dimensional blocks necessary for mortar yourself

node.title: Running input files in serial with same mesh and latest variables of previous file as IC
node.bodyText:
Hello
I am writing a bash script to run moose input files in serial mode. The variable values from last time step of previous input file are fed as initial condition for the next input file. However, I am getting a warning as follows. (detailed transition from previous to next moose input run is also pasted below)
�[31mLEGACY MODES ENABLED:�[39m
 This application uses the legacy material output option: material properties are output only on TIMESTEP_END, not INITIAL. To remove this message, set 'use_legacy_material_output' to false in this application. If there are gold output files that contain material property output for which output occurs on INITIAL, then these will generate diffs due to zero values being stored, and these tests should be re-golded.
�[39m

The initial value at time = 200 on the next input file is showing as zero. However, next time step onwards it begins with the latest run of previous initial conditions. How to get same value at time = 200 for both previous and next input runs.

To remove this message, set 'use_legacy_material_output' to false in this application. If there are gold output files that contain material property output for which output occurs on INITIAL, then these will generate diffs due to zero values being stored, and these tests should be re-golded.

Time Step 0, time = 0

Postprocessor Values:

Time Step 1, time = 2, dt = 2
 0 Nonlinear |R| = �[32m8.250601e-06�[39m

      0 Linear |R| = �[32m1.624317e-10�[39m
      1 Linear |R| = �[32m9.705998e-17�[39m
 2 Nonlinear |R| = �[32m1.479135e-17�[39m
�[32m Solve Converged!�[39m

Postprocessor Values:
+----------------+----------------+
| time           | min            |
+----------------+----------------+
|   0.000000e+00 |   0.000000e+00 |
|   2.000000e+00 |   5.693723e+02 |
+----------------+----------------+


Time Step 2, time = 4, dt = 2

Hello
You just need to modify the app file in src/base/.C and add in the parameters:
  params.set<bool>("use_legacy_material_output") = false;
this will remove the notice
Guillaume

Thanks. The warning in turned off now. But still at the first step of next file run the post processor values are show as 0.000000e+00.
Shouldn't it show the value of the latest step from the previous run file?
Postprocessor Values:
+----------------+----------------+
| time           | min            |
+----------------+----------------+
|   2.000000e+02 |   0.000000e+00 |
|   2.020000e+02 |   5.693723e+02 |
+----------------+----------------+

you ll need to execute the postprocessor on INITIAL for that
execute_on = 'INITIAL TIMESTEP_END' for example
Thanks.

node.title: Installing Moose on a local machine
node.bodyText:
Hello Everyone
I am a beginner and wanted to learn Moose. I have a Windows laptop with a window subsystem (WSL) installed on it. I am trying to install Moose using WSL but I am getting an error. Could someone please help me to install Moose on my laptop? I have attached a pdf with command that I am following and the error. Please let me know if there are further questions.
Thank you
Best
Moose_installation_error.pdf
Gaurav

Hello
you need to follow the prompt and restart the terminal after the first step.
Please feel free to paste (between triple quotes) the output of the console here (instead of pdfs or screenshots)
Guillaume

Hello
Thank you your quick reply. I did restart my terminal and followed the commands. Below is the output
(base) garora@adts141661-lt:~$ conda config --add channels https://conda.software.inl.gov/public
Warning: 'https://conda.software.inl.gov/public' already in 'channels' list, moving to the top

When I typed the following command
**mamba create -n moose moose-tools moose-libmesh**

**Could not solve for environment specs
Encountered problems while solving:
  - nothing provides deepdiff needed by moose-tools-2022.06.16-py37h6512ce3_0
  - nothing provides libpng 1.6.37 hed695b0_2 needed by moose-libmesh-2022.05.12-build_0

The environment can't be solved, aborting the operation**

I got the error shown above.

so the libmesh you are trying to install is very old. You should see something from march.
Could you please delete the environment then try again with mamba create -n moose moose-libmesh
what does python --version return?

Hello
when I tried to remove the environment by typing the command.
mamba env remove moose
it says no env to remove and also python --version gives me """ Python 3.10.8 """.
Also typing the command mamba create -n moose moose-libmesh gives me the same error.

Hello
I got the same error.
mamba create -n moose moose-libmesh-2023.03.29
Looking for: ['moose-libmesh-2023.03.29']
pkgs/main/linux-64                                            No change
pkgs/main/noarch                                              No change
pkgs/r/linux-64                                               No change
pkgs/r/noarch                                                 No change
https://conda.software.inl.gov/public/linux-64                No change
https://conda.software.inl.gov/public/noarch                  No change
Could not solve for environment specs
Encountered problems while solving:

nothing provides requested moose-libmesh-2023.03.29

Is there any other way on install it on windows?

well on windows-windows no. On WSL this should have worked.
If you're comfortable you can try the manual installation route, or we can wait for advice from Jason
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/getting_started/installation/manual_installation_gcc.html

Yeah, I guess I would wait as I don't have much knowledge about the packages and all. If I see no reply in few days then I might give it a shot. Well, I also want to mention that I tried installing using docker but failed. Looks like I was not even able to install docker on my laptop.

Some older versions or our packages were archived. I believe the version you are listing in your PDF attachment is one such version. Also, Python 3.7 has reached EOL, so we should switch that up to 3.10.
Some of the commands I am seeing being entered are incorrect. And that is the cause for some of your errors.
Let us delete the old faulty environment and start over:
Start from base environment:
mamba deactivate
mamba activate base
Delete old faulty environment:
mamba env remove -n moose
                 ^^
missed the -n argument
Install latest moose-libmesh and force the issue, that you want Python 3.10 instead of 3.7 you seem to be getting.
mamba create -n moose moose-tools moose-libmesh python=3.10
But if you need a specific version of moose-libmesh you need to specify that version with an '=' sign:
mamba create -n moose moose-libmesh=2023.03.29
                                   ^
= sign instead of -

Hello
I was able to remove the old env but when I tried to re-install it using mamba create -n moose moose-tools moose-libmesh python=3.10. I got the same error
"""Could not solve for environment specs
Encountered problems while solving:

nothing provides deepdiff needed by moose-tools-2022.06.16-py37h6512ce3_0
nothing provides libpng 1.6.37 hed695b0_2 needed by moose-libmesh-2022.05.12-build_0""".

Adding your PDF that I had to convert to text for reference (please refrain from posting images of text if you can)
Looking for: ['moose-tools' , 'moose- libmesh' ]

pkgs/main/noarch                                              No change
pkgs/r/linux-64                                               No change
bkgs/r/noarch pkgs                                            No change
/main/linux-64                                                No change
https://conda.software.inl.gov/public/linux-64                No change
https://conda.software. inl.gov/public/noarch                 No change
Could not solve for environment specs
Encountered problems while solving:
  - nothing provides deepdiff needed by moose-tools-2022.06.16-py37h6512c3 0
  - nothing provides libpng 1.6.37 hed6950_2 needed by moose-libmesh-2022.05.12-build_O
The environment can't be solved, aborting the operation

The hash identifier for moose-tools gives it away, that the system is trying to install Python 3.7:
moose-tools-2022.06.16-py37h6512c3
                       ^^^^  (py37 = Python 3.7)

node.title: Instructions for calling GPU to run input files
node.bodyText: I know the instruction to call the CPU to run the input.i files is'mpiexec -n 6 ./cat-opt -i input. i ', I want it to run faster. What is the instruction to call the GPU to run the input file?

See #21152
We dont have a full set of instruction anywhere else
